sn55.12:1.2: “Mendicants, the brahmins advocate a practice called ‘get up and go’.
sn55.12:1.4: ‘Please, good people, rising early you should face east and walk.
sn55.12:1.5: Do not avoid a pit, a cliff, a stump, thorny ground, a swamp, or a sewer.
sn55.12:1.6: You should await death in the place that you fall.
sn55.12:1.7: And when your body breaks up, after death, you’ll be reborn in a good place, a heaven realm.’
sn55.12:2.1: But this practice of the brahmins is a foolish procedure, a stupid procedure. It doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, or extinguishment.
sn55.12:2.2: But in the training of the Noble One I advocate a ‘get up and go’ practice
sn55.12:2.3: which does lead solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
sn55.12:3.1: And what is that ‘get up and go’ practice?
sn55.12:3.3: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …
sn55.12:3.7: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.
sn55.12:3.8: This is that ‘get up and go’ practice
sn55.12:3.9: which does lead solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.”
